item.title: Object Calisthenics #4: Implementations explanations
item.description:
The application of code rules is often conveyed as unidirectional and one-size-fits-all. In other words, when we learn to develop, we tend to read that there is only one way to produce quality code, and only one way to implement rules or patterns.
With this series of articles, we aim
item.author: (Pierre Belin, Yoan Thirion)

item.title: Sleep on it: How the brain processes many experiences — even when ‘offline’
item.description: In a new study, Yale researchers uncover how the brain, during sleep, replays and bundles many of the experiences that occur in our waking hours.

item.title: The Art of Finishing | ByteDrum
item.description: My endless battle with the "Project Hydra": why I can't seem to finish projects, and the strategies I'm exploring to finally complete what I start. A personal journey through productivity's thorniest challenge.
item.author: (Tomas Stropus)

item.title: DRY your Apache APISIX config
item.description: DRY is an important principle in software development. This post will show you how to apply it to Apache APISIX configuration. The DRY principle 'Don’t repeat yourself' (DRY) is a principle of software development aimed at reducing repetition of information which is likely to change, replacing it with abstractions that are less likely to change, or using data normalization which avoids redundancy in the first place. — https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself[Wiki
item.author: (Nicolas Fränkel)

item.title: Diffusion is spectral autoregression
item.description: A deep dive into spectral analysis of diffusion models of images, revealing how they implicitly perform a form of autoregression in the frequency domain.

item.title: How I’ve managed notes over 12 years
item.description: I have a Git repository dating back to 2012. Before that, I remember using Notational Velocity1 with a bunch of text files, it worked well, until I decided to keep my notes for life. If I’m not digitizing them, I’ll write notes on index cards and store them in boxes for organizing. As long as I can keep the boxes, I get to keep my notes. Notational Velocity is a text editor that lets me quickly search and switch between files. Later I switched to nvALT—a fork of Notational Velocity with some additional features and interface modifications, including MultiMarkdown functionality. ↩
item.author: (Tevin Zhang)

item.title: How to be better at making decisions
item.description: What can I do before, during, and after making decisions to be better at making them?

item.author: (Bryce Kerley)

item.title: Attention Is The Scarce Resource
item.description: There are, currently, a lot of high-profile people doing crazy stuff in public. Saying outrageous things, in interviews or on social media, that we would not have expected high-profile people to do a few decades ago (at least not in public). Any explanation of this, needs to not only explain why it happens so often now, but also why it hasn't always been happening. So, "people are crazy", "people are stupid", and that sort of thing, do not work as explanations, because that has always been true. Why in public now? Why the most high-profile people?
